<-- New York / LA differences.  One way is not necessarily better than the other. Just the difference between mayoral control and an elected school board with the cushion of a long-time administrator as interim.

Dec.: NYC's chancellor Faria steps down.  Jan.: LAUSD's supt. retires. District installs interim leader, launches search.  2/28: NYC hires a chancellor. 3/1: Supt stuns all, says oops no. 3/5 NYC has an actual chancellor.  3/14: Applications due for the LAUSD gig

ED wants details on getting to that 5%. They're also concerned that the exit criteria for underperforming schools could actually allow some schools that *decline in performance* to leave.
Remember how CA submitted an incomplete plan? How the current identification scheme for underperforming schools doesn't get to 5%? With a plan to amend? ED noticed.
Some specifics: ED is displeased at the lack of clarity around longterm goals for improving student performance, and specifically chides CA for not having goals for HS students in the plan.

@usedgov Many expected #ESSA approvals under the Trump administration  and DeVos in particular, who is focused on local control  to be a free for all. It is not.   Tl;dr: ED asked for clarification and significant changes in a 9-page addendum. CA has until 1/8 to resubmit.

@EdTrustWest @palewire Whatever the case, we published a list of the schools that were in the bottom 5% two years ago and stayed there in 2015. Half climbed out.pic.twitter.com/3gLUOAHJxL
@palewire On the Dashboard, it reads as average  a mismatch some advocates say is a problem, and officials say can be chalked up to different metricspic.twitter.com/NffQLArP0e
@palewire LAUSD told us the school has caught their attention, and they've seen gains in reclassifying English learners and internal reading tests.
@palewire But the Dashboard grades on a curve, meaning some schools w specific problems might be missed. This school in L.A. dropped from 12% to 7%.pic.twitter.com/yUcMXsJt3t
@palewire Why does this matter? The state will likely use this color-coded system, the CA School Dashboard, to whittle down its own 5%.pic.twitter.com/SOAVoWs4Xr
@palewire But theres bad news, too: 60 schools in the bottom 5% in 2015 actually saw drops in performance this year. Heres what they look like.pic.twitter.com/dJMCB2ZyyS
@palewire There's some good news here: In two years, they made double the progress of other schools statewide.pic.twitter.com/tvQ4swe8VB
@palewire Unsurprisingly, their scores were low: on average, in 2015, schools had 11.8% students meeting or exceeding goals in math, 6.6% in reading.pic.twitter.com/WmmuREiWyP
@palewire @Palewire isolated the schools in the bottom 5% in 2015. There were 451 of them spread across California.   50 concentrated in South L.A.pic.twitter.com/1VadeZeF9n
BUT. The Board of Ed submitted a plan to satisfy the law without a method to identify the schools that need help. Thats where we step in.pic.twitter.com/6s1EeDXlPZ
Under fed. law (#ESSA), CA must identify the bottom 5% of its schools. The state is moving away from using solely test scores to do that.pic.twitter.com/uHfn8ANYNh
